title: Line Up Metacarpals and Phalanges
summary: Use a distal-to-proximal sweep of the ray to spotlight landmark features and why they matter for splinting and fracture descriptions.
high_yield: Distinguish metacarpal bases (articulate with carpals) from heads (MCP knuckles).
Label the phalanx shaft vs. head vs. base so fracture nomenclature clicks.
3rd metacarpal styloid is a wrist alignment landmark; include it visually.
pitfalls: Learners mix up phalanx numbering (proximal/middle/distal). Use color coding per segment.
Thumb only has two phalanges—call it out during the intro sweep.

animation_timeline.narration: Zoom into the third ray, labeling metacarpal base, shaft, head, then proximal/middle/distal phalanges.
animation_timeline.visual: Highlight the 3rd ray with gradient; pop-up labels per segment.

animation_timeline.narration: Pan to the thumb ray to reinforce the two-phalange structure.
animation_timeline.visual: Thumb ray glow with text 'No middle phalanx' and icon.

animation_timeline.narration: Overlay common fracture callouts—Boxer’s (5th MC neck) and mallet finger (distal phalanx).
animation_timeline.visual: Animated brackets pointing to 5th metacarpal head and distal phalanx, with short text tags.
